p: The Writing Guidelines on Confluence contains style guidelines followed by the Nutanix Technical Publications team.
The purpose of all writing is to communicate clearly. These guidelines, and all writing guidelines, are never meant to obstruct clear communication.
The following subsections capture high-level guidance that applies across all of our technical writing.
h2: Use the Simple Present Verb Tense
p: Use simple present tense. In most cases, simple present tense is the correct choice for technical documentation.

p.span: Avoid accidentally slipping into future tense; this can happen with contractions like
Don't use complex verb tenses, which can be difficult for non-native English speakers to parse and can lead to low-quality translations.
Exception: If you're writing about past releases or test results, use the simple past tense.

p: Address your writing directly to the reader using the second-person pronoun you.

ul.li: Wrong: The end user can customize these settings.
Right: You can customize these settings.

p: Ensure that the subject of your sentence performs the action and doesn't just receive it.

ul.li: Passive voice: The component is set back to the supported settings by SCMA.
Active voice: SCMA resets the component to the supported settings.

p: When the subject of the sentence is missing altogether, using the passive voice can create confusion about what component or service is responsible for a product's behavior. Work with your Engineering team if you need help to determine what the subject should be.

ul.li: Passive voice: Traffic associated with the VM is monitored.
Active voice: Flow Network Security monitors the traffic associated with the VM.
